author: DroperidolEveryone
body: Haven’t seen that personally but I’ve seen a lot of ozempic induced pancreatitis.

author: BadSloes2020
body:
I had one patient who fried his pancreas 

no etoh, no gall stones, normal triglycerides   on ozempic and functionally became a type one diabetic in his 60s

A1c>14 on the plus side he lost a bunch more weight peeing out all that glucose.

author: allegedlys3
body: Ah so THATS the trick

author: alphabet_order_bot
body:
Would you look at that, all of the words in your comment are in alphabetical order.

I have checked 1,908,370,734 comments, and only 360,827 of them were in alphabetical order.

author: Alert_Client_427
body: oh yeah?

author: SpoofySpoon
body: I’ve seen gastroparesis but no pancreatitis from PCP land

author: teatimecookie
body: Nucmed checking in. We already do a lot of GEMPS, now we have to do more & listen to the bitching about microwaved eggs.

author: SpoofySpoon
body: Can you break down that acronym and the eggs?

author: teatimecookie
body: GEMPS is a gastric emptying scan that we microwave radioactive eggs for. Most people don’t like microwaved eggs, shocking I know.

author: AustinCJ
body: Focal bowel ischemia as well.

author: Extension_Economist6
body: any risk factors? any young pts?

author: DroperidolEveryone
body: Yes. A we have one girl who is 30 who has spent like 6 out of the last 9 weeks in the hospital from pancreatitis flares. No other risk factors. It’s anecdotal, but she never had any pancreatitis issues before starting ozempic.

author: Extension_Economist6
body: damn 😔

author: whirlst
body: Switched to? The only treatment for type 1 diabetes is insulin. Hopefully no one is stopping insulin in these patients.

author: Igotdiabetus
body: Ya. At no point should a type 1 diabetic be on glp1 solo therapy. Glp1 type meds can help a lot with insulin resistance and reducing overall insulin needs however

author: t3stdummi
body: Hard to ask the pancreas that doesn't make insulin to secrete more insulin.

author: speedracer73
body: You can always ask. Like asking the psych unit to take a suicidal patient with K of 3.1

author: Sofakinggrapes
body: As a consult psychiatrist this made me laugh lol.

author: Burnsy112
body: Wait what?

author: broadcity90210
body: I believe one of my patients said he was still using insulin for mealtime coverage. So you’re right, they are still using some insulin. But that same guy had a pH of 7, anion gap over 33, +ketones, AKI, & lipase levels through the roof. His BG was only in the high 200’s/low 300’s at the time too so I’m not sure how he went south so fast

author: RigilNebula
body:
If you spend any time reading forums for type 1 diabetes, it's extremely common for these patients to encounter health care professionals (both in and out of hospital) who have no idea how to treat their diabetes, or who provide dangerous advice. 

This sometimes includes telling the diabetic that they don't need insulin because, due to their age and/or weight, they must be type 2.

It's almost a mantra for type 1 diabetics to never let anyone (other than their endocrinology team) manage their diabetes, even in hospital, for this reason.

author: StepUp_87
body: Well, obviously you can’t switch an individual with Type 1 to Ozempic that would indeed cause DKA rather swiftly. What’s likely happening when Ozempic gets added to their regimen is the patient is decreasing their insulin intake below what their body’s physiological threshold/needs are for insulin and then of course ketones start to be produced. I’ve had multiple patients report having to back off their fast acting insulin while using GLP-1’s so much that they eliminate meal bolusing altogether . I’ve also seen the pancreatitis. And AKI resulting in HD…. It’s a much more difficult balance and endocrinologists are hard to come by in certain areas.

author: broadcity90210
body: This makes so much sense. Yeah I agree it’s a difficult balance!

author: Weekly-Plate-3176
body:
20 year T1D vet! Im 23F ; diagnosed @4 and have always had extreme insulin resistance. 1-3/1-2 carb ratio even while on extreme work out months (soccer). They put me on ozempic to help with the weight gain from the extreme insulin resistance. For ref; 4’11 @230lbs. Not ideal. Throughout my life my blood sugars have been a constant roller coaster. Other than the three weeks I would go to spend at diabetes camp in the summer. This has been the only drug that has actually plateaued my blood sugars to stay at the minimal level that they should be at however, the side effects are excruciatingly uncontrollable. 

This past December, I ended up in the ER throwing up like the fucking exorcist. In my mother’s words I’ve never heard a human being sound like that. 

Did you not? I just got off the phone with my endocrinologist an hour ago and it seemed like she had no fucking clue that this was going to possibly even be a considerable issue.  Seeing other people are continuously experiencing similar situation’s. This breaks my heart, because this has been the only thing that has helped with my blood sugars…. And lose the unnecessary wheat bread on to me by this horrible disease. :((

author: halp-im-lost
body:
Ozempic can reduce the amount of insulin a T1DM patient needs but that doesn’t mean they should be switched to it entirely. If you don’t have insulin to get sugar into your cells DKA is going to happen. Are these patients you’re seeing getting taken off of their insulin completely?

Anecdotally I have not seen any DKA from Ozempic. Thus far I’ve seen on patient who suffered nausea and vomiting from it. The one patient I thought had pancreatitis from it actually had choledocolithiasis haha

author: broadcity90210
body: No I worded that poorly! Sorry about that. But they are using significantly less insulin for mealtime coverage than they did before being on Ozempic. So maybe that’s contributing to it

author: ArtichosenOne
body: please tell me no doctor is switching a DM1 off of insulin to Ozempic.  if you see this, report them to the board.

author: looknowtalklater
body: Lots of Ozempoparesis;epigastric pain, constipation, nausea.  Lots of Ozepogastria on CT-dinner from 3 days ago causing gastric distention.

author: bevespi
body:
Outpatient FM… I’ve had zero patients have severe complications. I’ve had many report side effects. I’ve had many become successful at weight loss and DM control. EM often sees the worst of the worst where I often seen the best of the best outcomes. There’s going to be selection bias. Those that do well won’t be as loud as those that unfortunately have had significant complications.

Also, it’s not insulin. Don’t get rid of insulin in T1DM.

author: lasixpissing
body:
There will be a huge recall on Ozempic, it's only a matter of time. 

Making individuals' intestinal motility abnormal is neither safe nor a solution to obesity.

author: JakeArrietaGrande
body: We’re hearing about individual cases with problems, because it’s part of introducing a new drug. We’re not hearing about the good it’s doing, the reduced heart attacks, strokes, knee replacements and every other complication of obesity, but I feel those will far outweigh the small number of individual cases that have a lot of side effects

author: OlivesFlowers
body: Except for all the people using it cosmetically. Rich people seem to be suddenly scary thin

author: JakeArrietaGrande
body: Yeah man. I can understand the risk profile if you’re obese, and haven’t had luck with traditional methods, it absolutely makes sense. But it really doesn’t make sense to do it just for the last 10 pounds or so

author: skywayz
body: You’re seeing people with normal BMIs on Ozempic ? I’ve yet to see that, but anecdotally I have seen lots of success stories of people who have lost a significant amount of weight on it. But also seen a few complications from it too, many of the cases were due to inappropriate titration though.

author: differing
body: Keep in mind there are plenty of online pill mills that have pivoted from ED drugs to ozempic. They aren’t exactly doing a thorough physical exam via zoom!

author: OlivesFlowers
body: Tbf, it is a ton of celebrities, I haven't seen everyday friends/family taking it to get extra skinny. But online seems to make it really accessible. I just really don't want this super skinny actress/real housewife phenomenon to lead to a second wave of the 90s heroine-chic. My psyche can't deal with that again lol

author: Sekmet19
body:
I hope not. I've lost 60lbs and have had no adverse effects.  I titered up slowly over the course of a year. I make sure to eat healthy, high protein meals because I know I'm eating a lot less and that means I need to make each meal count. I drink plenty of water and have dissolvable fiber I take to help with constipation. 

We should be looking at those who are having these adverse events and comparing them to those without and seeing if there are risk factors.  If you're eating garbage when you do eat that might be a factor.  If having a comorbid condition like an autoimmune disorder or a sludgey gallbladder increases risk we should investigate.

My back pain resolved, my nocturia resolved, my sob with climbing stairs resolved, I stopped snoring (I likely had sleep apnea), I sleep better, and I feel better. I'm getting treated better too, people are much nicer to me which is unfair I'm literally the same person but I realize that people treat you better if you are more attractive and being overweight isn't generally considered attractive.

Let's look at the data and make decisions from there.

author: mezotesidees
body: I saw some lit about ESRD patients being at higher risk

author: [deleted]
body: Glad I’m not the only one who isn’t a fan of the Ozempic boom

author: madcul
body: Well GLP 1 agonists have been around a long time, do you think Ozempic causes issues that other ones don’t?

author: Hippo-Crates
body:
>Making individuals' intestinal motility abnormal is neither safe nor a solution to obesity.

That's not how glp-1 drugs work. It's a thing that happens sure, but it's not the mechanism of how they work. The data for it working against obesity is about as good as one could reasonably get, and  a mortality benefit has been shown in people with DM or CVD.

author: [deleted]
body: [deleted]

author: skywayz
body:
Lol what exactly is your idea of a long term solution here? Bypass surgery, a gastric sleeve? I don’t know how we think physically making your stomach smaller is better than taking a pill. And before you say it, yes I realize lifestyle and dietary changes is the long term solution. But that’s been known for years, and the obesity epidemic in this country is only getting worse. 

That being said if these medications long term end up showing a significant side effect, it is something absolutely to take into consideration. But even if there is a side effect you need to weigh it against the benefits of weight loss vs the plethora of complications from obesity.

author: coastalhiker
body:
It’s diet. Once you lose a significant amount of weight, your body does really calibrate to smaller meals and lower calories. 


And as I said, the answer may be pulsed therapy. Get to goal wight, come off, and see if they can maintain. If not, then maybe go back on and try again. 


I agree that obesity is not good either and should definitely be a risks/benefits discussion. But, for most people, if you get them down to a normal weight, many of them can likely come off the meds. 


And hell no to bypass or sleeve. I would certainly prefer these drugs to surgery.

author: Hippo-Crates
body: Why is it a bad long term one? What are you basing these guesses on?

author: ShalomRanger
body:
“In a clinical trial of semaglutide, the active ingredient in Ozempic and Wegovy, researchers looked at loss of lean muscle mass in a subgroup of 140 participants. On average, participants lost about 15 pounds of lean muscle and 23 pounds of fat during the 68-week trial.”

https://www.nejm.org/doi/suppl/10.1056/NEJMoa2032183/suppl_file/nejmoa2032183_appendix.pdf

author: Hippo-Crates
body: That’s not relevant to anything. It shouldn’t be surprising to you that people losing large amounts of weight lose both fat and muscle

author: ShalomRanger
body: Oh it’s relevant big boy. Roll damn tide

author: opinionated_cynic
body: It’s been around a long time and increases health and QoL for many many people.

author: buttpugggs
body:
I'm overweight myself so when I saw more and more talk about it I was naturally curious.

I did about 5mins of reading before I was like, "Nah, I'm just going to keep doing as I'm doing by going to the gym and not eating like a pig." Ozempic sounds like a terrible idea and it looks like people are basically hailing it as a miracle.

author: Stepane7399
body: It probably is when you are unable to muster up the discipline to do it the preferred way.

author: [deleted]
body: I’ve been saying that eventually we’re gonna see those commercials in 10-20 years saying, “have you or a loved one developed ____ after taking ozempic, wegovy, and monjaro? Well you might be entitled to compensation.”

author: Maxifer20
body: I was on it for a period of time, and stopped having a normal menstrual cycle. That getting messed up threw my hormones out of wack and I had worsening depression and increased suicidality. Didn’t see the side effect of abnormal menstruation on their website, but talked to my PCP, who said many other female pts were reporting the same, but were cool with having fewer periods. There’s a lot that’s going to come out, I think.

author: Roosterboogers
body: About a month ago, I saw a DKA on T2DM but this was from gastroparesis caused/worsened by Ozempic

author: FourScores1
body: Yeah, taking a type 1 off insulin tends to put them in DKA regardless of what else they are taking. Their bodies don’t make insulin. It needs to be supplemented.

author: tapeduct-2015
momma1RN
body: Ummmm it’s not indicated for type 1. Ever. Type 1 diabetics need insulin so if they are on ozempic, yeah makes sense they could be in DKA 🤦🏼‍♀️🤦🏼‍♀️

author: revumol7
body: Not seen DKA but have seen a handful of GI bleeds after starting Ozempic… they were pretty bad bleeds too

author: Nurse_Hamma
body: Ozempic is not approved for type 1 diabetics, if it is being used it is off label. I have seen it in someone with  lot of insulin resistance and type 1 but it was in conjunction with an insulin pump and CGM.

author: KumaraDosha
body: Tangential question, but is there any opinion on whether or not Ozempic is more useful/less risk of side effects in prediabetics as opposed to the severely diabetic?

author: renslips
body: Report every single physician who has been prescribing this for T1D. It is NOT appropriate for this use because it leads to this exact situation.

author: jkordsm
body: No doctor would do this lol

author: renslips
body: Good thing OP is a nurse

author: ggarciaryan
body: I don't think GLP1s are indicated for DM 1, though they are being studied actively.

author: [deleted]
body:
could someone please comment on the utility of using GLP-1s in T1DM? 

I assume we are looking for better glucose control with the glucose dependent mechanism, but I'm confused since the patient will be on basal/bolus insulin already, so it doesnt really seem like this adds enough utility to justify the cost. 

I get that lower a1c is probably better in terms of preserving organ function, but adding a glp-1 to a type 1 patient seems silly unless they are terrible at complying with their insulin regimen and refuse to improve.

author: fuzzy_bunny85
body: The commercial explicitly says that it’s not for people with Type 1 DM..

author: darling_nikki85
body: I am LADA and very insulin resistant and treated as type 1. When I was still producing a lil bit of insulin I was put on trulicity and it was very effective but then my insurance wouldn't cover it even tho my Dr showed them how it was working for me. Then she put me on ozempic I was on that for a few months and it wasn't as effective but still helping some but then I had a DKA episode and she said it was due the other ozempic and took me off of it. I'm still trying to figure out how to combat this insulin resistant cause I take a crazy amount of insulin. My sister is type 1 and she takes a fraction of what I take.

author: ryrace
body: My mom is type II diabetic and was on trulicity then ozempic and had a DKA episode. She’s never had one before and has been in the hospital for 3 days. If these meds don’t work for diabetics what other options are there?

author: RobbieNguyen
body: Unrelated but I heard there was an ICU nurse at my hospital that did not have any DM diagnosis but somehow was prescribed Ozempic( I'm assuming for weight loss) had gone into cardiac arrest while I was working across the street with my cardiologist and they were called over immediately...Unfortunately, the nurse did not make it.

author: Certain_Resort328
body: Type 1 diabetics are usually not obese

author: runforitmarty3418
body: 60% actually are
